Definition.Description: Flint Hills Resources used Seeq to deploy anomaly detectors across their fleet of over 4000 pieces of equipment and effectively triage these results, allowing them to predict failures early and enable profitable actions. Learn more here   Problem Statement: By identifying leading and lagging indicators of pump health and continuously
Definition.Document:
Pump Health Monitoring

Problem Statement:

By identifying leading and lagging indicators of pump health and continuously monitor these indicator variables, poor performance can be detected and corrective actions can be taken.

Deviation from Pump Curve

Solution:

Access the raw data, display the pumps process signal.

  • Some signals that can be used to calculate KPIs providing insight into overall pump health might include: flow rates, discharge and suction pressures, suction temperature, upstream tank level (static head), vibration data, and pump status signals. 
  • Additional contextual data that can be helpful in evaluating pump performance might include: pump curve, pump data sheet, liquid properties, and failure or maintenance event data. 

Cleanse the raw signals by easily removing the downtime and outliers.

  • Signal filtering can be applied to remove noise from signals. Outliers and downtime data should be removed from signals when calculating monitoring limits. Interpolation settings can be adjusted to leave gaps in the data during long outages and linearly interpolate through point outliers. Signals can be repaired to read zero when an unreasonable negative flow reading occurs.
  • Identify downtimes or periods when the pump is not operating
  • Remove downtime data, outliers, smooth signals
    • Suction Temperature
    • Recirculation Flow
    • Discharge Pressure
    • Discharge Flow Rate
    • Drum Level
    • Suction Pressure
  • Convert liquid property data, like API to SG 

Identify when process data deviates +/- 30% from the design pump curve. Pump curves can be plotted using Seeq Add-on tool, Plot Digitizer
(Do it! Create a notification for when the pump is not in normal operation)

  • Calculate Total Flow through the pump (discharge + recirculation)
  • Using the pump curve data, calculate the design discharge pressure from the total flow
  • Create +/- 30% boundary limits for design discharge pressure
  • Identify when pump is operating outside of design window

Identify the indicators, unique operating modes, based on deviation from the Best Efficiency Point (B.E.P. on reference image below). (all indicators)

  • With pump curve/design operation incorporated into Seeq, we can begin to define other operating modes based on deviation from the Best Efficiency Point (B.E.P. on image below).

  • Based on pump curve, the best operating point is at flowrate of 290 GPM (9942.86 bbl/day)which corresponds with 8100 ft .  Normal operating mode  is usually around ±10% BEP flowrate (8948  to 10937 bbl/day) . Other operating modes are identified based on how far the pump is being operating at from BEP. 
    • High Temp Rise (less than 3977bbl/d)
    • Low Flow Cavitation (3977 to 4971 bbl/d)
    • Low bearing/seal life (low flow) (4971 to 5966 bbl/d)
    • Reduced impeller life (5966 to 6960 bbl/d)
    • Suction recirculation (6960 to7954 bbl/d)
    • Discharge recirculation ( 7954 to 8948 bbl/d)
    • Low bearing/seal life (high flow) (10937 to 11931 bbl/d)
    • High flow cavitation  (higher than 11931 bbl/d)
    • Cavitation due to low NPSH
    • Normal operation (8948  to 10937 bbl/day)

Quantify the total duration of each indicator on days of the year.

Pump Health Monitoring

Problem Statement:

By identifying leading and lagging indicators of pump health and continuously monitor these indicator variables, poor performance can be detected and corrective actions can be taken.

Deviation from Pump Curve

Solution:

Access the raw data, display the pumps process signal.

  • Some signals that can be used to calculate KPIs providing insight into overall pump health might include: flow rates, discharge and suction pressures, suction temperature, upstream tank level (static head), vibration data, and pump status signals. 
  • Additional contextual data that can be helpful in evaluating pump performance might include: pump curve, pump data sheet, liquid properties, and failure or maintenance event data. 

Cleanse the raw signals by easily removing the downtime and outliers.

  • Signal filtering can be applied to remove noise from signals. Outliers and downtime data should be removed from signals when calculating monitoring limits. Interpolation settings can be adjusted to leave gaps in the data during long outages and linearly interpolate through point outliers. Signals can be repaired to read zero when an unreasonable negative flow reading occurs.
  • Identify downtimes or periods when the pump is not operating
  • Remove downtime data, outliers, smooth signals
    • Suction Temperature
    • Recirculation Flow
    • Discharge Pressure
    • Discharge Flow Rate
    • Drum Level
    • Suction Pressure
  • Convert liquid property data, like API to SG 

Identify when process data deviates +/- 30% from the design pump curve. Pump curves can be plotted using Seeq Add-on tool, Plot Digitizer
(Do it! Create a notification for when the pump is not in normal operation)

  • Calculate Total Flow through the pump (discharge + recirculation)
  • Using the pump curve data, calculate the design discharge pressure from the total flow
  • Create +/- 30% boundary limits for design discharge pressure
  • Identify when pump is operating outside of design window

Identify the indicators, unique operating modes, based on deviation from the Best Efficiency Point (B.E.P. on reference image below). (all indicators)

  • With pump curve/design operation incorporated into Seeq, we can begin to define other operating modes based on deviation from the Best Efficiency Point (B.E.P. on image below).

  • Based on pump curve, the best operating point is at flowrate of 290 GPM (9942.86 bbl/day)which corresponds with 8100 ft .  Normal operating mode  is usually around ±10% BEP flowrate (8948  to 10937 bbl/day) . Other operating modes are identified based on how far the pump is being operating at from BEP. 
  • High Temp Rise (less than 3977bbl/d)
  • Low Flow Cavitation (3977 to 4971 bbl/d)
  • Low bearing/seal life (low flow) (4971 to 5966 bbl/d)
  • Reduced impeller life (5966 to 6960 bbl/d)
  • Suction recirculation (6960 to7954 bbl/d)
  • Discharge recirculation ( 7954 to 8948 bbl/d)
  • Low bearing/seal life (high flow) (10937 to 11931 bbl/d)
  • High flow cavitation  (higher than 11931 bbl/d)
  • Cavitation due to low NPSH
  • Normal operation (8948  to 10937 bbl/day)

Quantify the total duration of each indicator on days of the year.
